job_title: Patient Access Representative in Lafayette, LA
pros: Salary is very competitive. Probably the highest paying employer for PARs
cons: Poor management. More work is asked of you constantly without increase in pay. Patient Access is treated as a non-essential part of the hospital.

pros: Flexible hours, yearly raise, license provided through hospital.
cons: Call ins often, management needs guidance.

review_title: If you want a raise go anywhere else.
pros: Awesome co-workers and doctors for the short time they worked there. New building, unfortunately whoever designed it was not in the medical field.
cons: Incompetence is rewarded...the dumbest, laziest, rudest, most ethically challenged people are promoted to management (one manager was even fired as a supervisor and rehired as a manager). Management likes to threaten and yell at employees. One manager liked to tell the nurses that if they didn't like it there, they were replaceable with new graduates (funny, all the new grads go to LGMC and OLOL  is now resorting to hiring travel nurses whose families moved from ebola hot zones). Wages are some of the lowest unless you come in on a travel contract. If you are hoping for a raise, you will be told straight out on hire not to expect more than 1% . There is no sign on bonus...another hospital in the area offers a $4,000 sign on bonus. Don't expect specialty pay if you already work there and transfer to a specialty area. You will not be treated like a person. You will work short handed and told to "roll with it." You will constantly be told by management to be grateful you even have a job and that you are replaceable. When something happens, management will attempt to lie to save their own butts, even when it doesn't make sense and they are obviously lying.

pros: This is a great company
cons: Nothing bad to say about them at all

pros: Mission based organization, new facilities, some employee events - halloween, movie appreciation day, etc.
cons:
Most of the management don't actually follow the mission, lots of backstabbing and politics. Huge amount of turnover. HR doesn't really care about the employees, they just move people through like cattle from the interviews, to the onboarding paperwork and orientation. Orientation is a joke, you get paid to sit through a day of powerpoint slides and when you get out of orientation you realize that everything they said doesn't reflect everyday behavior of the employees and managers.  For orientation, don't be late or have any tattoos showing, because the guy running it will call you out or tell your boss. The pay is anywhere from 15-20% lower than other hospitals in the area, the reasoning is that it's a non-profit, but that's such a small part of the organization.  They talk about the mission and environment making up for the low pay, but the environment is toxic and the mission is just given lip service.  They openly talk about the other hospitals being terrible places to work often, it almost seems like insecurity...

Essentially, Lourdes talks about the franciscan mission, but most of the people that have been there for a long time are just lifers that don't care about a mission at all and are just waiting to retire...

pros: Nursing co-workers were a great team
cons: Hospital admin with little respect for nurses, low pay, HR terrible

review_title: Very humbling experience when it comes to professionalism
pros: Very loving and caring environment, however the facility is very firm in its mission and you must really be dedicated and have some type of connection with a higher power to understand is for philosophy in some aspects however me being a spiritual person and I found it to be very refreshing
cons: I want to mess up you get one chance and no other chances. What’s in my belief is it totally Christ like. As stated by its mission per st Francis

Chain of command only exists for appearances. Low pay. Raises- forget about it.
